abstract.para: A short description of all SPARK-PL commands.

sect2.title: null
sect2.para:
null : $NullObject
The null object (reference). Can be used for testing results of some operations.

Example
var a = self as GoodAgent if a != null [ do-something ]

sect2.title: pi
sect2.para: Mathematical pi constant, 3.1415926…

sect2.title: true
sect2.para: Logical true value. Can be assigned only to a Boolean variable

sect2.title: false
sect2.para: Logical false value.

sect2.title: circle
sect2.para: A circle shape.

sect2.title: square
sect2.para: A square shape. Affects only visual appearance of the corresponding space agent.

sect2.title: square2
sect2.para: A square shape. Affects both visual appearance and the collision detection algorithm of the corresponding space agent.

sect2.title: torus
sect2.para:
A torus shape.
Note: right now shapes can be used only in the following context: agent SomeAgent : SomeAgentDerivedFromSpaceAgent to create super 0.5 circle end That is, shapes are available only for agents derived from SpaceAgent, and shapes should be assigned using super command (which can be used without errors also only for SpaceAgent) with two arguments: radius and shape.

sect2.title: Colors
sect2.para: black, white, grey, red, green, blue, cyan, magenta, yellow, brown, orange, violet, pink. Note: all colors are treated as vectors. So, instead of colors it is possible to use vectors in the RGB format where each component is between 0 and 1 (smaller and bigger values are ignored).

sect1.title: Operations
sect1.para: Note: all operations (with few obvious exceptions) require two arguments. All operations are infix which means that the arguments are written from left and right sides from the operation symbol (e.g. 2 * 3).

Note: infix operations have precedence, that is, the order in which they are applied. The precedence is usual so no problems should occur but in any case it is possible to use parentheses to change the precedence.
Note: ignore type expressions after colons if you are not familiar with them, instead read descriptions.

sect2.para:
^ : double->double->double
Power. Works only for numbers.

Example:
a^b, 2^3.14, pi^pi

*,/ : double -> double -> double, double -> vector -> vector, vector -> double -> vector *,/ : double -> complex, complex -> double, complex -> complex
Multiplication, division. Works with real and complex numbers and with a vector on one side and a real number on another side.

Example:
var x : double var v : vector x = x * 3 v = v / 4 v = v * 2 x = 2 * 2

sect2.title: * (dot)
sect2.para:
* : vector -> vector -> number
A dot product of two vectors.

% : double -> double -> double
Returns the residual of a division

Example:
if tick % 10 == 0 [ print "True if the tick is a multiple of ten" ]

+, - : double -> double -> double, vector -> vector -> vector +, - : double -> complex -> complex, complex -> double -> complex, complex -> complex -> complex
Addition, subtraction: work both for numbers and vectors.

sect2.title: + (string concatenation)
sect2.para:
+ : string -> string -> string, string -> double -> string, string -> boolean -> string + : string -> vector -> string
Concatenates two strings or a string and a primitive value.

<, > , >=, <=: double -> double -> boolean
Comparison operations. Work for numbers only.

==, != : double -> double -> boolean, boolean -> boolean -> boolean ==, != : $NullObject -> $NullObject -> $NullObject
Equality, inequality. Work for any types. The only condition is that the types are compatible (that is, do not compare a vector and a number, etc.) Advanced note: actually, it is possible to compare, for instance, a vector and a grid since both of them are objects of the type $NullObject.

sect2.title: - (unary)
sect2.para:
- (unary) : double -> double, complex -> complex, vector -> vector
Unary minus. Also works as a negation operation for vectors.

sect2.title: and, or
sect2.para:
and, or : boolean ->boolean -> boolean
Logical operators AND and OR. Can be applied only to boolean arguments.

sect2.title: not
sect2.para:
not : boolean -> boolean
Logical negation.

Example:
If not true == false [ print "OK" ]

=, +=, *=, -=, /=
Assignment operations from programming languages like C++, Java, C#.
+=, -= work with both numbers and vectors.
*=, /= work with numbers and with a vector on LHS (the left hand side) and a number on RHS.
*= works with a grid on LHS and a number on RHS.

sect2.title: is
sect2.para:
variable is type : boolean
variable : $Object type : $type
Checks whether an object on LHS is of type on RHS. Returns a boolean value.

Example:
var v : vector if v is vector [ print "A vector is a vector"] if v is grid [print "A vector is a grid"]
In this example only the first sentence will be printed out.

sect2.title: as
sect2.para:
variable as type : extends $Object
variable : $Object type : $type
Converts a given variable to a given type and returns a conversion result. If the conversion is not possible then the special null value is returned.

Example:
var agent-list = all-agents-here ask agent-list [ var good-agent = self as GoodAgent if good-agent == null [ continue ] ; do something with good-agent ]
In this example a list of all agents at the position of the calling (current) agent is obtained. By default, the type of each agent in this list is SpaceAgent. Then all agents in the list are processed (by ask command). New variable 'good-agent' is created with the value of the currently processed agent converted to GoodAgent type. If the conversion was unsuccessful then continue with the next agent in the list.

sect2.title: abs
sect2.para:
abs value : number value : number, complex
Returns the absolute value of a given number.

sect2.title: acos
sect2.para:
acos value : number value : number
Returns the arccosine of the argument measured in radians.

sect2.title: asin
sect2.para:
asin value : number value : number
Returns the arcsine of the argument measured in radians.

sect2.title: atan
sect2.para:
atan value : number value : number
Returns the arctangent of the argument measured in radians.

sect2.title: atan2
sect2.para:
atan2 x y : number x : number y : number
Converts rectangular coordinates (x,y) to polar (r, theta) and returns theta.

sect2.title: ceil
sect2.para:
ceil value : number value : number
Returns the smallest value that is not less than the argument and is equal to an integer.

sect2.title: cos
sect2.para:
cos value : number, complex value : number, complex
Returns the cosine of the argument measured in radians.

sect2.title: exp
sect2.para:
exp value : number, complex value : number, complex
Returns the exponent of the argument.

sect2.title: floor
sect2.para:
floor number : number number : number
Rounds the number towards zero.

sect2.title: log
sect2.para:
log value : number value : number
Returns the natural logarithm of the argument.

sect2.title: round
sect2.para:
round number : number number : number
Rounds a number.

sect2.title: sgn
sect2.para:
sgn number : number number : number
Returns the sign of the argument.

sect2.title: sin
sect2.para:
sin value : number, complex value : number, complex
Returns the sine of the argument measured in radians.

sect2.title: sqrt
sect2.para:
sqrt number : number number : number
Returns the square root of a number.

sect2.title: tan
sect2.para:
tan number : number, complex number : number, complex
Returns the tangent root of the argument measured in radians.

sect1.title: Commands
sect1.para: Note: command descriptions are in the following format: Command name followed by arguments separated by whitespaces. If a command has a return value then after the colon the type of the return value is given. On the next lines arguments listed with their types after colons.
Note: special types (types which cannot be declared explicitly) are started with $ symbol.

List of special types:
$type
A name of any type (except number/double).
$integer
Type of integer numbers.
$NullObject
Any object type which can assume the null value.
$Object : $NullObject
Any object type (not 'double' or 'boolean').

sect2.title: add-grid-space
sect2.para:
add-grid-space name x-min x-max y-min y-max wrap-x wrap-y : Space name : string x-min : number y-min : number x-max : number y-max : number wrap-x : boolean wrap-y : boolean
Adds a new Grid space into a model. Call it in the model setup method. 'name' is the name of a new space. It can be used for getting a reference to this space with 'get-space' command.

Note: it is required to have one space declared with 'space' keyword. That space is considered to be the default space and is always used when no explicit reference to a space is given. Also, that default space has the name 'space' so it is prohibited to use the name 'space' for additional spaces.
Example: see 'add-standard-space'

sect2.title: add-physical-space
sect2.para:
add-physical-space name x-min x-max y-min y-max wrap-x wrap-y : Space name : string x-min : number y-min : number x-max : number y-max : number wrap-x : boolean wrap-y : boolean
Adds a new Physical space into a model. Call it in the model setup method. 'name' is the name of a new space. It can be used for getting a reference to this space with 'get-space' command.

Note: it is required to have one space declared with 'space' keyword. That space is considered to be the default space and is always used when no explicit reference to a space is given. Also, that default space has the name 'space' so it is prohibited to use the name 'space' for additional spaces.
Example: see 'add-standard-space'

sect2.title: add-standard-space
sect2.para:
add-standard-space name x-min x-max y-min y-max wrap-x wrap-y : Space name : string x-min : number y-min : number x-max : number y-max : number wrap-x : boolean wrap-y : boolean
Adds a new standard space into a model. Call it in the model setup method. 'name' is the name of a new space. It can be used for getting a reference to this space with 'get-space' command.

Note: it is required to have one space declared with 'space' keyword. That space is considered to be the default space and is always used when no explicit reference to a space is given. Also, that default space has the name 'space' so it is prohibited to use the name 'space' for additional spaces.

Example:
; Default space space GridSpace -20 20 -20 20 true true
global another-space : Space
to setup another-space = add-standard-space "One more space" (-10) 10 (-10) 10 true false
; Agents will be created in default space create SomeAgent 2
; Agents will be created in another-space ask another-space [ create SomeAgent 20 ask create-one AnotherAgent [ set-random-position ] ] end
In this example a new space is created inside setup method. In this case grids cannot be created inside that new space. See 'create-grid-in-space' command to resolve this issue.

sect2.title: add-standard3d-space
sect2.para:
add-grid-space name x-min x-max y-min y-max z-min z-max wrap-x wrap-y wrap-z : Space name : string x-min : number y-min : number z-min : number x-max : number y-max : number z-max : number wrap-x : boolean wrap-y : boolean wrap-z : boolean
Adds a new Standard3d space into a model. Call it in the model setup method. 'name' is the name of a new space. It can be used for getting a reference to this space with 'get-space' command.

Note: it is required to have one space declared with 'space' keyword. That space is considered to be the default space and is always used when no explicit reference to a space is given. Also, that default space has the name 'space' so it is prohibited to use the name 'space' for additional spaces.
Example: see 'add-standard-space'

sect2.title: agents
sect2.para:
agents type : List<type> type : $type
Returns a list of all agents of a specific type.

Example:
var all-good-agents = agents GoodAgent var number-of-macrophages = count agents Macrophage
There is a better way to get the number of specific agents, that is, use agents-number command.

Note: only the agents which have precisely the requested type are returned.
agent Agent1 : Agent
agent Agent2 : Agent1
to get-agents1 ; Only agents of type 'Agent1' will be returned. ; No agents of type Agent2 will be in the returned agent list. var agents1 = agents Agent1 end

sect2.title: agents-at
sect2.para:
agents-at type point radius : List<type> type : $type point : vector radius : number
Returns all agents in the default space of a specific type at the specific circular region (given by its center ‘point’ and radius ‘radius’). The radius cannot be negative. Zero radius means that the agents at a point are requested.

Example:
var good-agents-at-the-origin = agents-at GoodAgent [0,0,0] 0

sect2.title: agents-at-as
sect2.para:
agents-at-as type point radius : List<type> type : $type point : vector radius : number
Returns all agents in the default space derived from a specific type at the specific circular region (given by its center ‘point’ and radius ‘radius’). The radius cannot be negative. Zero radius means that the agents at a point are requested.

sect2.title: agents-as
sect2.para:
agents-as type : List<type> type : $type
Returns all agents derived from a specific type.

sect2.title: agents-here
sect2.para:
agents-here type : List<type> type : $type
Returns all agents of a specific type intersecting with the current active agent.
Note: only agents can call this function.
Note: agents in the same space as the calling agent are returned.
Note: the calling agent is also returned if its type is the same as the requested one.

sect2.title: agents-here-as
sect2.para:
agents-here-as type : List<type> type : $type
Returns all agents derived from a specific type intersecting with the current active agent.
Note: only agents can call this function.
Note: agents in the same space as the calling agent are returned.
Note: the calling agent is also returned if its type is derived form the requested one.

sect2.title: agents-number
sect2.para:
agents-number type : number type : $type
Returns the number of agents of a specific type.

sect2.title: agents-number-as
sect2.para:
agents-number-as type : number type : $type
Returns the number of agents derived from a specific type.

sect2.title: all-agents-at
sect2.para:
all-agents-at point radius : List<SpaceAgent> point : vector radius : number
Returns all agents in the default space at a given circular region. Type of all returned agents is SpaceAgent. Look at 'as' operation example to see how to convert this type to other types.

sect2.title: all-agents-here
sect2.para:
all-agents-here : List<SpaceAgent>
Returns all agents at the position of the calling agent.
Note: agents in the same space as the calling agent are returned.

sect2.title: ask
sect2.para:
ask list [commands] list : List, Array, $Object
Iterates through all objects in the list and performs commands for each object. Commands are given in brackets. 'self' inside the command block refers to the currently processed object from the list. 'myself' inside the command block refers to the object which called 'ask' command.
Note: if list == null, then no commands will be executed.

Example:
ask all-agents-here [ var good-agent = self as GoodAgent ask good-agent [ ; the same as self.color = blue color = blue ; actually, the previous command do the same ; thing as ; myself.color = blue ; because good-agent variable refers to the same object as ; self variable from the outer ask command block. ] ]
Note: in the example above 'as' command could return null value, but it is not a problem since 'ask' command correctly works with null list and object arguments.

sect2.title: break
sect2.para:
break
This command is equivalent to 'break' keyword in C, C++, Java, C#. It can be used only inside commands which iterate over some values. This command tells to stop the current iterative process ('while', 'for', 'repeat', or 'ask') and continue executing commands after that process.

Example:
repeat 100 [ if true [ break ] ] var y = 0 for x = 1:100 [ if x == 50 [ break ] y += x ]

sect2.title: complex
sect2.para:
complex re im : complex re : double im : double
Creates a complex number with the given real and imaginary parts.

sect2.title: continue
sect2.para:
continue
This command is equivalent to 'continue' keyword in C, C++, Java, C#. It can be used only inside commands which iterate over some values. This command tells to start the next iteration immediately.

Example:
repeat 100 [ if true [ continue ] ] var y = 0 for x = 1:100 [ if x == 50 [ continue ] y += x ]

sect2.title: count
sect2.para:
count list : number list : List, Array
Returns the number of elements in a list (array).

sect2.title: create
sect2.para:
create type number : Array<type> type : $type number : number
Creates 'number' of objects of type 'type'. Cannot be used with types 'number' and 'boolean'. Commonly used for creating new agents.

Example:
create GoodAgent 1000 create BadAgent 1 var vectors = create vector 100 ; creates an array of vectors ask create SomeAgent 20 [ set-random-position ]

sect2.title: create-circle
sect2.para:
create-circle radius : ShapeInfo radius : double
Creates a circular shape description. Used for changing shapes of agents during a simulation process.
Note: this command works only for physical agents in a physical space.

Example
; SimpleAgent agent SimpleAgent : SpaceAgent
to create super 0.4 dynamic-circle ; equivalent to ; radius = 0.7 shape = create-circle 0.7 end
; Model model Demo
space PhysicalSpace2d -10 10 -10 10 false false

sect2.title: create-rect
sect2.para:
create-rect hx hy : ShapeInfo hx : double hy : double
Creates a rectangular shape description. Used for changing shapes of agents during a simulation process.
Note: this command works only for physical agents in a physical space.

Example
; SimpleAgent agent SimpleAgent : SpaceAgent
to create super 0.4 dynamic-circle shape = create-rect 0.2 1 end
; Model model Demo
space PhysicalSpace2d -10 10 -10 10 false false

sect2.title: create-file-reader
sect2.para:
create-file-reader fname : Reader fname : string
Creates a reader object for the given text file. Returns null if the file with the given name does not exist or if it cannot be open.

Example
var lines = create-list string
ask create-file-reader "data.txt" [ ; Read all lines while true [ var line = read-line if line == null [ break ]
; Ignore comments if line.starts-with "#" [ continue ]
lines.add line ]
; Close the reader close ]

sect2.title: create-file-writer
sect2.para:
create-file-writer fname : Writer fname : string
Creates a writer object for the given text file. Returns null if the file with the given name cannot be open. This command creates a new file if there is no file with the given name. Note: files are created in the output folder of a running SPARK model.

Example
ask create-file-writer "data.txt" [ write-num 1 write-num 2
; Close the writer close ]

sect2.title: create-new-file
sect2.para:
create-new-file file-name file-name : string
Creates a new file with the given name. If a file with the given name exists, then it will be deleted and a new file with the same name will be created. Note: files are created in the output folder of a running SPARK model.

Example
create-new-file "test.log"

sect2.title: create-unique-file
sect2.para:
create-unique-file name-prefix name-prefix : string
Creates a new file with the given name. If another file with the given name exists, then the name is modified such that a new file has its own unique name. Note: files are created in the output folder of a running SPARK model.

Example
create-unique-file "test"

sect2.title: create-one
sect2.para:
create-one type : Type of this command equals to 'type' type : $type
Creates one object of a specific type. The main difference form the 'create' command with number = 1 is that the type of this command is different.

Example
(create-one GoodAgent).color = red ; it is not possible to write the following ; (create GoodAgent 1).color = red ; because the command in parentheses has type Array

sect2.title: create-grid
sect2.para:
create-grid name x-size y-size : grid name : string x-size : number y-size : number
Creates a grid with a given name and of a given dimension in the default space. This command can be used in the grid declaration code inside a model class.

Note: if no grid initialization is given for a grid, then the default initialization will be created with the name equals to variable's name and with the dimension of the default space. So the only use of this command is to create grids of different resolutions.
Note: in the current implementation 'name' should be the same as variable's name.

Example:
model Model global data = create-grid "data" 10 10

sect2.title: create-grid3d
sect2.para:
create-grid3d name x-size y-size z-size : grid3d name : string x-size : number y-size : number z-size : number
Creates a 3-dimensional grid. See create-grid for additional information.

sect2.title: create-grid-in-space
sect2.para:
create-grid space name x-size y-size : grid space : Space, string name : string x-size : number y-size : number
Creates a grid with a given name and of a given dimension in a given space. This command can be used in the grid declaration code inside a model class.
Note: the space should be initialized before this command.
Note: in the current implementation 'name' should be the same as variable's name.

Example:
model Model
; Default space space StandardSpace -20 20 -20 20 true true
; Additional space global space2 = add-standard-space "space2" (-10) 10 (-10) 10 true false
; Grid will be created in the default space global data = create-grid "data" 10 10
; Grid will be created in space2 global data2 = create-grid-in-space space2 "data2" space2.x-size space2.y-size
; Grid will be created in the default space with the default size global data3 : grid

sect2.title: create-list
sect2.para:
create-list type : List<$type> type : $type
Creates a list which can contain object of the given type.

Example:
; Create a list of strings var list = create-list string
list.add "first" list.add "second"

sect2.title: create-vector
sect2.para:
create-vector x y z : vector x : number y : number z : number
Creates a new vector with the given components

sect2.title: current-time-millis
sect2.para:
current-time-millis : double
Returns the current system time in milliseconds.

sect2.title: delaunay-triangulation
sect2.para:
delaunay-triangulation list-of-agents link-type list-of-agents : List<SpaceAgent> link-type : $type (should be derived from SpaceLink)
Computes Delaunay triangulation of points representing centers of agents in the list. Agents in the list will be connected by links of the given type when the triangulation is computed.

Example:
; Kill all existing MyLink's kill agents MyLink ; Compute Delaunay triangulation and connect agents with MyLink's delaunay-triangulation (agents TestAgent) MyLink

sect2.title: distance
sect2.para:
distance agent1 agent2 : vector agent1 : SpaceAgent agent2 : SpaceAgent
distance pos1 pos2 : vector pos1 : vector pos2 : vector
Returns the vector v equals to agent2.position – agent1.position (pos2 - pos1). It does more: in the torus topology the shortest vector-distance is returned.

Example:
; get the vector-distance between agents and then compute the length of this vector var distance-between-agents = (distance agent1 agent2).length

sect2.title: diffuse
sect2.para:
diffuse grid value grid : grid (DataLayer), grid3d value : number
Performs the diffusion operation on a given grid. 'value' is the diffusion coefficient.

The diffusion operation is performed as follows. Each data layer cell shares (coefficient * 100) percents of its value with its eight neighbors. The coefficient should be between 0 and 1 for a well-defined behavior.

sect2.title: evaporate
sect2.para:
evaporate grid value grid : grid (DataLayer), grid3d value : number
Performs the evaporation operation on a given grid. 'value' is the evaporation coefficient.
Evaporation simply means multiplication of all data layer values by the given value.

sect2.title: exit
sect2.para:
exit
This command ends the current method. Only methods that do not return any value can use this command. Other methods should use 'return'.

sect2.title: for
sect2.para:
for var-name = from : step : to [] (a special syntax, not a type definition) for from : to [] (another form with step = 1 by default) from : double step : double to : double
A loop command for iterating values of the given variable from 'from' to 'to' with the step size 'step'.
Note: var-name should be a unique name, no other local variables with the same name should exist in the method using a 'for' loop.

sect2.title: fprint
sect2.para:
fprint file-name object file-name : string object : $Object, string, number
Prints a text representation of the given object into the given file. If a file with the given name doesn't exist, then a new file will be created. If a file with the given name exists, then a new text line will be appended to the end of this file.

Example
fprint "test.log" "2 + 2 = " fprint "test.log" (2 + 2) ; The following two lines will be added to the file "test.log": ; 2 + 2 = ; 4
See create-writer and Writer object for another way of creating files in SPARK.

sect2.title: get
sect2.para:
get list index list : List, Array index : number
Returns an element from the list at the position specified by the index.

sect2.title: get-grid
sect2.para:
get-grid name : $DataLayer name : string
Returns a grid with the given name.

sect2.title: get-space
sect2.para:
get-space name : Space name : string
Returns a space with the given name. Default space has name 'space'.

sect2.title: if
sect2.para:
if condition [commands] condition : boolean
A standard if control statement. If the condition is true, then the commands will be executed.

sect2.title: ifelse
sect2.para:
ifelse condition [commands1][command2] condition : boolean
A standard if-else control statement. If the condition is true, then commands from the first block will be executed, otherwise commands from the second block will be performed.

sect2.title: interpolate
sect2.para:
interpolate v1 v2 t : vector (number) v1 : vector (number) v2 : vector (number) t : number
This command is a slightly optimized version of v1 * (1 - t) + t * v2

sect2.title: is-key-pressed
sect2.para:
is-key-pressed key-name : boolean key-name : string
Returns true if the key with the given name is pressed.

sect2.title: is-mouse-button-pressed
sect2.para:
is-mouse-button-pressed button : boolean button : double
Returns true if the given mouse button is pressed (1 = left button, 2 = right button).

sect2.title: kill
sect2.para:
kill agent-list agent-list : List, Array, $Object
Kills all agents in the list, that is, this command calls 'die' for each agent in the list. This command is a shortcut for
ask agent-list [ die ]

sect2.title: max
sect2.para:
max a b : number a : number b : number
Returns the maximum of two numbers.

sect2.title: min
sect2.para:
min a b : number a : number b : number
Returns the minimum of two numbers.

sect2.title: mouse-position
sect2.para:
mouse-position : vector
Returns the current mouse position.

sect2.title: myself
sect2.para:
myself : $Object
Returns a reference to the calling agent. See 'ask' for more information.

sect2.title: next-key-event
sect2.para:
next-key-event : KeyEvent
Returns the next keyboard event from the keyboard event queue. Returns null if the queue is empty.

Example
var left-pressed : bool
; Process all keyboard events while true [ var event = next-key-event if event == null [ break ]
; Left arrow event if event.name == "left" [ left-pressed = event.pressed ] ]

sect2.title: next-mouse-event
sect2.para:
next-mouse-event : MouseEvent
Returns the next mouse event from the mouse event queue. Returns null if the queue is empty

sect2.title: normal-random
sect2.para:
normal-random mean std : double mean : double std : double
Returns a normally distributed random number.

sect2.title: num2int
sect2.para:
num2int n : $integer n : double
Converts the given floating point number to an integer number.

sect2.title: one-of
sect2.para:
one-of list : Type of elements of list list : List, Array
Returns one randomly selected element of the given list.
Note: the list argument should be not null.

sect2.title: parent
sect2.para:
parent : $Object
Returns a reference to the parent class of the current class.

sect2.title: print
sect2.para:
print str str : string, double, boolean, $Object
Prints out a string

sect2.title: random-in-interval
sect2.para:
random-in-interval a b : number a : number b : number
Returns a uniformly distributed random number in the interval [a,b).

sect2.title: random
sect2.para:
random a : number a : number
Returns a uniformly distributed random number in the interval [0, a)

sect2.title: random-vector
sect2.para:
random-vector a b : vector a : number b : number
Returns a random vector with uniformly distributed components in the interval [a, b).
Note: this function returns a random 2-d vector with the third component 0.

sect2.title: random-vector3
sect2.para:
random-vector a b : vector a : number b : number
Returns a random vector with uniformly distributed components in the interval [a, b).
Note: this function returns a random 3-d vector.

sect2.title: random-vector-of-length
sect2.para:
random-vector-of-length length : vector length : number
Returns a random vector of the given length.
Note: this function returns a random 2-d vector with the third component 0.

sect2.title: random-vector3-of-length
sect2.para:
random-vector-of-length length : vector length : number
Returns a random vector of the given length.
Note: this function returns a random 3-d vector.

sect2.title: repeat
sect2.para:
repeat number [commands] number : number
Repeats commands the given number of times.

sect2.title: return
sect2.para:
return value
Returns the given 'value' as method’s value.
Note: the type of 'value' should be compatible with method’s return type.

sect2.title: self
sect2.para:
self : $Object
Returns a reference to the active object (agent).

sect2.title: set
sect2.para:
set list index value list : List, Array index : number value : Type of elements of the list
Sets a new value for the element at the specific position of the list.

sect2.title: space-xmin
sect2.para:
space-xmin : number
Returns the minimum x coordinate of the default space.

sect2.title: space-xmax
sect2.para:
space-xmax : number
Returns the maximum x coordinate of the default space.

sect2.title: space-ymin
sect2.para:
space-ymin : number
Returns the minimum y coordinate of the default space.

sect2.title: space-ymax
sect2.para:
space-ymax : number
Returns the maximum y coordinate of the default space.

sect2.title: space-xsize
sect2.para:
space-xsize : number
Returns the size of the default space along x-axis. That is, space-xmax – space-xmin.

sect2.title: space-ysize
sect2.para:
space-ysize : number
Returns the size of the default space along y-axis. That is, space-ymax – space-ymin.

sect2.title: sum
sect2.para:
sum list : number list : grid, grid3d
Returns a total sum of all data values stored in a grid.

sect2.title: this
sect2.para:
this : $Object
Returns a reference to the current object.

sect2.title: to-string
sect2.para:
to-string arg : string n : number, boolean, $integer, vector, $Object
Converts the argument into a string.
Note: the argument should be not null.

sect2.title: truncate
sect2.para:
truncate v min max : vector v : vector min : number max : number
Truncates all components of a given vector.

sect2.title: use-primary-random-generator
sect2.para: Tells the simulation engine to use the primary random generator for producing random numbers.
Note: the primary random generator is used by default.

sect2.title: use-secondary-random-generator
sect2.para: Tells the simulation engine to use the secondary random generator for producing random numbers.
Switching to the secondary generator is useful in cases when it is required to generate some random numbers which should not affect a simulation output.

sect2.title: vector-in-direction
sect2.para:
vector-in-direction length angle : vector length : number angle : number
Returns a vector of length 'length' in the direction specified by 'angle'.
Note: the angle should be measured in degrees.
Note: a 2-d vector is returned.

sect2.title: while
sect2.para:
while condition [commands]
Commands in the block are executed while the condition is true.

sect1.title: string
sect1.para: Methods and fields of the 'string' class.

sect2.title: split
sect2.para:
split regexp : List<string> regexp : string
Splits the string object into a list of strings based on the given regular expression (Java regular expression syntax).

Example
var str = "first,second" var list = str.split "," ; Prints "first" print (get list 0) ; Prints "second" print (get list 1)

sect2.title: trim
sect2.para:
trim : string
Removes leading and ending spaces in the string object.

Example
var str = " first, second " var list = str.split "," ; Prints "first" print (get list 0) ; Prints "second" print (get list 1)

sect2.title: to-num
sect2.para:
to-num : number
Converts the string object into a number.

Example
var str = "12.4" var x = str.to-num + 1 ; Prints 13.4 print x

sect2.title: to-int
sect2.para:
to-int : $integer
Converts the string object into an integer number.

sect2.title: starts-with
sect2.para:
starts-with str : boolean str : string
Returns true if the string object starts with the given substring.

Example
var str = "first,second" ; Prints 'true' print str.starts-with "first"

sect2.title: substring
sect2.para:
substring begin end : string begin : number end : number
Returns a substring of the string object with the first symbol specified by the 'begin' index, and the last symbol specified by the 'end' index (indices start from 0).
Note: the 'end' index is exclusive, that is, the substring symobls have 'begin', 'begin' + 1,..., 'end' - 1 indices in the original string.

Example
var str = "first,second" ; Prints "st,s" print str.substring 3 7

sect2.title: substring-end
sect2.para:
substring-end begin : string begin : number
Returns a substring of the string object which starts at the 'begin' index.

Example
var str = "first,second" ; Prints "econd" print str.substring-end 7

sect2.title: char-at
sect2.para:
char-at i : number i : number
Returns the code of a symbol at the given position in the string object.

sect1.title: List
sect1.para: Methods and fields of list objects.

sect2.title: add
sect2.para:
add object object : $Object (the type should be compatible with the list subtype)
Adds an object to the list object.

Example
var list = create-list string list.add "first"

sect2.title: add-all
sect2.para:
add-all list list : List<type> (the type should be compatible with the list subtype)
Adds all objects from the argument to the list object.

Example
var list = create-list string var list2 = create-list string list.add "first" list2.add "second" list2.add "third"
list.add-all list2

sect2.title: add-all-at
sect2.para:
add-all-at index list index : number list : List<type> (the type should be compatible with the list subtype)
Adds all objects from the argument to the list object starting at the specified position.

sect2.title: add-at
sect2.para:
add-at index object index : number object : $Object (the type should be compatible with the list subtype)
Inserts an object to the list at the specific location.

Example
var list = create-list string list.add "second" list.add-at 0 "first"

sect2.title: clear
sect2.para:
clear
Removes all elements from the list object.

sect2.title: set
sect2.para:
set i val i : number val : $Object (the type should be compatible with the list subtype)
Sets a new value at the given index.
Note: the index should be less than the length of the list.

Example
var list = create-list string
ask list [ add "first" set 0 "new first" ]

sect2.title: remove-at
sect2.para:
remove-at i i : number
Removes an element at the given index.

Example
var list = create-list string list.add "first" list.add "second" list.remove-at 0 ; Now the list has only 1 element: "second"

sect2.title: remove
sect2.para:
remove object object : $Object (the type should be compatible with the list subtype)
Removes the given object from the list. If the object is not inside the list, then the list is not changed.

Example
var list = create-list string list.add "first" list.add "second"
list.remove "second" list.remove "third";
; Now the list has 1 element: "first"

sect2.title: remove-all
sect2.para:
remove-all list-arg list-arg : List<type> (the type should be compatible with the list subtype)
Removes all elements of the argument from the list object.

This command is equivalent to the following code
ask list-arg [ list.remove self ]

sect2.title: contains
sect2.para:
contains object : boolean object : $Object (the type should be compatible with the list subtype)
Returns true if the list contains the given object.

sect1.title: vector
sect1.para: Methods and fields of the 'vector' class.

sect2.title: x
sect2.para:
x : number
The first component of a vector.

sect2.title: y
sect2.para:
y : number
The second component of a vector.

sect2.title: z
sect2.para:
z : number
The third component of a vector.

sect2.title: length
sect2.para:
length : number
Returns the length of a vector.

sect2.title: length-squared
sect2.para:
length-squared : number
Returns the squared length of a vector.

sect2.title: normalize
sect2.para:
normalize : vector
Normalizes a vector and returns a reference to itself.

sect2.title: truncate-length
sect2.para:
truncate-length max-length : vector max-length : number
If the length of a vector is higher than 'max-length' then its length is truncated to 'max-length'. Otherwise, the vector is unchanged. A reference to itself is returned.

sect2.title: copy
sect2.para:
copy : vector
Returns a copy of a vector.

sect2.title: dot
sect2.para:
dot v : number v : vector
Computes the dot product with a given vector.

sect2.title: cross
sect2.para:
cross v : vector v : vector
Computes the cross product with a given vector. The result overrides the current vector's value.

sect2.title: parallel-component
sect2.para:
parallel-component unit-vector : vector unit-vector : vector
Returns a component of a vector parallel to a given unit vector.
Note: the argument vector should be of a unit length for this method to yield a correct result.
This method computes: (u,v) * u, where u is the argument, and v is the vector object.

sect2.title: perpendicular-component
sect2.para:
perpendicular-component unit-vector : vector unit-vector : vector
Returns a component of a vector perpendicular to a given unit vector.
Note: the argument vector should be of a unit length for this method to yield a correct result.
This method computes: v - (u,v) * u

sect1.title: complex
sect1.para: Methods and fields of a class for complex numbers.

sect2.title: re
sect2.para:
re : number
Returns the real part of a complex number.

sect2.title: im
sect2.para:
im : number
Returns the imaginary part of a complex number.

sect2.title: abs
sect2.para:
abs : number
Returns the absolute value of a complex number.

sect2.title: arg
sect2.para:
arg : number
Returns the polar argument of a complex number.

sect2.title: reciprocal
sect2.para:
reciprocal : complex
Computes the inverse of a complex number.

sect2.title: conjugate
sect2.para:
conjugate : complex
Returns the conjugate of a complex number.

sect1.title: Reader
sect1.para: A class for reading text files.

sect2.title: close
sect2.para:
close
Closes an open file.

sect2.title: read-line
sect2.para:
read-line : string
Returns the next line from an open file. Returns null if no new lines are available.

Example
ask create-reader "test.txt" [ ; Read all lines while true [ var line = read-line if line == null [ break ]
; Process the line ]
; Close the file close ]

sect2.title: read-num
sect2.para:
read-num : number
Reads a number from a file.

sect2.title: read-bool
sect2.para:
read-bool : boolean
Reads a boolean value from a file.

sect2.title: read-int
sect2.para:
read-int : $integer
Reads an integer from a file.

sect2.title: read-vector
sect2.para:
read-vector : vector
Reads a vector from a file.

sect1.title: Writer
sect1.para: A class for writing text files.

sect2.title: close
sect2.para:
close
Closes an open file.

sect2.title: write-line
sect2.para:
write-line line line : string
Writes a string into a file.

sect2.title: write-num
sect2.para:
write-num n n : number
Writes a number into a file.

sect2.title: write-bool
sect2.para:
write-bool b b : boolean
Writes a boolean value into a file.

sect2.title: write-vector
sect2.para:
write-vector v v : vector
Writes a vector into a file.

sect2.title: write-object
sect2.para:
write-object obj obj : $Object
Converts the given object into a string and writes this string into a file. If the object is null, then "null" is written into a file.

sect2.title: pressed
sect2.para:
pressed : boolean
Returns the status of the key for this event.

sect2.title: name
sect2.para:
name : string
Returns the name of the key for this event.

sect2.title: space-name
sect2.para:
space-name : string
Returns the space name for which the event was created.

sect2.title: event-type
sect2.para:
event-type : string
Returns the type of the event. Possible types are: "LBUTTON_DOWN", "LBUTTON_UP", "RBUTTON_DOWN", "RBUTTON_UP", "MBUTTON_DOWN", "MBUTTON_UP", "MOUSE_MOVE", "MOUSE_WHEEL".

sect2.title: position
sect2.para:
position : vector
Returns the mouse position for the event.

sect2.title: buttons
sect2.para:
buttons : $integer
Returns the mouse button states for the event.

sect2.title: wheel
sect2.para:
wheel : $integer
Returns the mouse wheel state for the event.

sect2.title: space-name
sect2.para:
space-name : string
Returns the space name for which the event was created.

sect2.title: create
sect2.para:
create type number : $Array<type> type : $type (derived from SpaceAgent) number : number
Creates 'number' of agents of the type 'type' in a specific space.

Example:
; Create 1000 GoodAgent in the space "Space2". ask get-space "Space2" [ create GoodAgent 1000 ]

sect2.title: create-one
sect2.para:
create-one type : Type of this command equals to ‘type’ type : $type (derived from SpaceAgent)
Creates one agent of a specific type in a given space. The main difference form the previous command with number = 1 is that the type of this command is different.

Example
var space1 = add-standard-space (-10) 10 (-20) 20 true false (space1.create-one GoodAgent).color = red ; it is not possible to write the following ; (space1.create GoodAgent 1).color = red ; because the command in parentheses has type $Array

sect2.title: x-min
sect2.para:
x-min : number
Returns the minimum x coordinate of a space.

sect2.title: x-max
sect2.para:
x-max : number
Returns the maximum x coordinate of a space.

sect2.title: y-min
sect2.para:
y-min : number
Returns the minimum y coordinate of a space.

sect2.title: y-max
sect2.para:
y-max : number
Returns the maximum y coordinate of a space.

sect2.title: x-size
sect2.para:
x-size : number
Returns the size of a space along the x-axis. That is, x-max – x-min.

sect2.title: y-size
sect2.para:
y-size : number
Returns the size of a space along the y-axis. That is, y-max – y-min.

sect2.title: agents-at
sect2.para:
agents-at type point radius : List<type> type : $type point : vector radius : number
Returns all agents in a given space of a specific type at the specific circular region (given by its center ‘point’ and radius ‘radius’). Radius cannot be negative. Zero radius means that the agents at a point are requested.

sect2.title: agents-at-as
sect2.para:
agents-at-as type point radius : List<type> type : $type point : vector radius : number
Returns all agents in a given space derived from a specific type at the specific circular region (given by its center ‘point’ and radius ‘radius’). Radius cannot be negative. Zero radius means that the agents at a point are requested.

sect2.title: all-agents-at
sect2.para:
all-agents-at point radius : List<SpaceAgent> point : vector radius : number
Returns all agents in a given space at a given circular region. Type of all returned agents is SpaceAgent.

sect2.title: agents-here
sect2.para:
agents-here type : List<type> type : $type
Returns all agents of a specific type intersecting with the current active agent.
Note: only agents can call this function.
Note: agents in a given space are returned.
Note: the calling agent may also be returned if its type is the same as requested one.

sect2.title: agents-here-as
sect2.para:
agents-here-as type : List<type> type : $type
Returns all agents derived from a specific type intersecting with the current active agent.
Note: only agents can call this function.
Note: agents in a given space are returned.
Note: the calling agent may also be returned if its type is derived from requested one.

sect2.title: all-agents-here
sect2.para:
all-agents-here : List<SpaceAgent>
Returns all agents at the position of a calling agent.
Note: agents in a given space are returned.

sect2.title: die
sect2.para:
die
Destroys an agent.

sect2.title: is-dead
sect2.para:
is-dead : boolean
Returns true if the calling agent is dead.

sect2.title: all-links
sect2.para:
all-links : List<AbstractLink>
Returns all links of this agent.

sect2.title: link
sect2.para:
link agent : Link agent : Agent
'link a' returns a link if the active agent is connected to 'a', or 'null' if there is no link between the active agent and 'a'.

sect2.title: link-of-type
sect2.para:
link-of-type link-type link-type : Link
Return a link of the specific type connected to the current agent.

sect2.title: links-of-type
sect2.para:
links-of-type link-type link-type : List<link-type>
Returns all links of the given type connected to the current agent.

sect1.title: AbstractLink
sect1.para: A base class for all links.

sect2.title: connect
sect2.para:
connect end1 end2 end1 : Agent end2 : Agent
Connects two agents with the link.

sect1.title: Link : AbstractLink
sect1.para: A link class for space agents.

sect2.title: color
sect2.para:
color : vector
Link's color.

sect2.title: width
sect2.para:
width : number
Link's width (used for visualization only).

sect2.title: end1
sect2.para:
end1 : SpaceAgent
Returns the first end of the link.

sect2.title: end2
sect2.para:
end2 : SpaceAgent
Returns the second end of the link.

sect2.title: distance
sect2.para:
distance : vector
Returns a vector distance between agents connected by the link.

sect2.title: move
sect2.para:
move v v : vector
Adds 'v' to the current position and moves the space agent to that new position.

sect2.title: get-agent-space
sect2.para:
get-agent-space : Space
Returns the space in which the space agent is located.

sect2.title: move-to
sect2.para:
move-to pos pos : vector
Moves the space agent to a new position.

sect2.title: move-to-space
sect2.para:
move-to-space new-space new-position new-space : Space new-position : vector
Moves an agent to a given space at a specific position inside that space.

sect2.title: set-random-position
sect2.para:
set-random-position
Moves an agent to a random position inside a space.

sect2.title: hatch
sect2.para:
hatch type number : Array<type> type : $type (derived from SpaceAgent) number : number
Creates ‘number’ of agents of type ‘type’ in the same space as a calling agent and at the same position as a calling agent.

sect2.title: hatch-one
sect2.para:
hatch-one type : Type of this command equals to ‘type’ type : $type (derived from SpaceAgent)
Creates one agent of a specific type in the same space as a calling agent and at the same position as a calling agent. The main difference form the previous command with number = 1 is that the type of this command is different.

sect2.title: position
sect2.para:
position : vector
Field 'position' is the position of an agent inside a space. This is a read only field. To assign a value to the position use 'move-to' or 'move' methods.

sect2.title: color
sect2.para:
color : vector
Field 'color' is the color of a space agent.

sect2.title: radius
sect2.para:
radius : number
Field 'radius' is the size of a space agent.

sect2.title: label
sect2.para:
label : string
Field 'label' of the space agent. Labels of space agents could be visualized during a simulation process.

sect2.title: alpha
sect2.para:
alpha : number
Field 'alpha' determines the transparency of the space agent. If alpha = 0, then the agent is completely transparent. If alpha = 1, then the agent is completely opaque.

sect2.title: rotation
sect2.para:
rotation : number
Rotation of the agent in the xy-plane (measured in degrees).

sect2.title: fixed-rotation
sect2.para:
fixed-rotation : boolean (set only)
If true, then the physical simulation engine will not attempt to rotate the agent. Works only for physical agents.

sect2.title: restitution
sect2.para:
restitution : number
Field 'restitution'. Works only for physical agents.

sect2.title: shape
sect2.para:
shape : ShapeInfo (set only)
Field 'shape'. Allows to change agent's shape dynamically. Works only for physical agents. See create-circle and create-rect commands for examples.

sect2.title: update-proxy
sect2.para:
update-proxy
A special command for physical agents. In general, should be called when a physical agent is moved to a new position with 'move' or 'move-to' methods.

sect2.title: set-collision-category
sect2.para:
set-collision-category category category : number
Sets a collision category of a physical agent. A collision category is an integer number from 0 to 15.

sect2.title: add-collision-category
sect2.para:
add-collision-category category category : number
Adds a collision category to a physical agent. A collision category is an integer number from 0 to 15.

sect2.title: add-collision-mask
sect2.para:
add-collision-mask mask mask : number
Adds a collision mask to a physical agent. A collision mask is an integer number from 0 to 15.

sect2.title: remove-collision-category
sect2.para:
remove-collision-category category category : number
Removes a collision category from a physical agent. A collision category is an integer number from 0 to 15.

sect2.title: remove-collision-mask
sect2.para:
remove-collision-mask mask : number
Removes a collision mask from a physical agent. A collision mask is an integer number from 0 to 15.

sect2.title: apply-force
sect2.para:
apply-force force force : vector
Applies the given force to a physical agent.

sect2.title: apply-impulse
sect2.para:
apply-impulse impulse impulse : vector
Applies the given impulse to a physical agent.

sect2.title: get-velocity
sect2.para:
get-velocity : vector
Returns a velocity vector of a physical agent.

sect2.title: max
sect2.para:
max : number
Returns the maximum value stored in a grid.

sect2.title: min
sect2.para:
min : number
Returns the minimum value stored in a grid.

sect2.title: total-value
sect2.para:
total-value : number
Returns the sum of all values stored in a grid.

sect2.title: total-value-in-region
sect2.para:
total-value-in-region x-min x-max y-min y-max : number x-min : number x-max : number y-min : number y-max : number
Returns the sum of all values stored in a grid in a specific region.

sect2.title: multiply
sect2.para:
multiple coefficient coefficient : number
Multiplies all values in a grid by a given coefficient.

sect2.title: evaporate
sect2.para:
evaporate coefficient coefficient : number
Multiplies all values in a grid by a given coefficient (this is an alias for the 'multiply' method).

sect2.title: diffuse
sect2.para:
diffuse coefficient coefficient : number
Performs a diffusion operation on a grid with a given diffusion coefficient.

The diffusion operation is performed as follows. Each data layer cell shares (coefficient * 100) percents of its value with its eight neighbors. The coefficient should be between 0 and 1 for a well-defined behavior.

sect2.title: set-value
sect2.para:
set-value value value : number
Sets all values in a grid to a given value.

sect2.title: data-at
sect2.para:
data-at i j : number i : number j : number
Returns a value in a cell (i, j).

sect2.title: set-data-at
sect2.para:
set-data-at i j new-value i : number j : number new-value : number
Sets the value of a cell (i, j) to a new value.

sect2.title: get-xsize
sect2.para:
get-xsize : number
Returns the number of cells in a grid along x-axis.

sect2.title: get-ysize
sect2.para:
get-xsize : number
Returns the number of cells in a grid along y-axis.

sect2.title: get-smooth-gradient
sect2.para:
get-smooth-gradient point : vector point : vector
Returns a gradient at the given point.

sect2.title: value-at
sect2.para:
value-at pos : number pos : vector
Returns a value corresponding to a given position.

sect2.title: set-value-at
sect2.para:
set-value-at pos new-value pos : vector new-value : number
Sets the value of a cell corresponding to a given position.

sect2.title: add-value-at
sect2.para:
add-value-at pos num pos : vector num : number
Adds a given number to the value of a cell corresponding to a given position.

sect2.title: value-here
sect2.para:
value-here : number
Returns a value corresponding to the position of a calling space agent.

sect2.title: set-value-here
sect2.para:
set-value-here new-value new-value : number
Sets the value of a cell corresponding to the position of a calling space agent.

sect2.title: add-value-here
sect2.para:
add-value-here num num : number
Adds a given number to the value of a cell corresponding to the position of a calling space agent.

sect2.title: value
sect2.para:
value : number
The field 'value' is the value of a cell corresponding to the position of a calling space agent.
